newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Ivorian 96/97 main cocoa crop seen above 1.0 mln T.
newsitem.headline: Ivorian 96/97 main cocoa crop seen above 1.0 mln T.

text.p: Ivory Coast's 1996/97 cocoa main crop (Oct-April) is set to exceed one million tonnes but is unlikely to match the 1.04-1.05 million tonnes seen in the record 1995/96 season, industry sources said on Monday.
Arrivals of cocoa at ports totalled 982,157 tonnes by April 12, compared to 1.03 million by the same date last year, sources said.
Arrivals have since ranged between 5,000 to 10,000 tonnes per week, they added.
Port sources said 677,638 tonnes of cocoa had been taken to Ivory Coast's main port of Abidjan by April 12 with the remainder declared at the second port, San Pedro.
Ivory Coast produced a record 1.2 million tonnes in 1995/96, with yield boosted by favourable weather and improved maintenance.

It has not upgraded its output forecast of 950,000 tonnes for this year -- despite industry estimates that the 1996/97 total would be up to 1.15 million tonnes, based on crop analysis and higher-than-expected arrivals.
Local analysts' preliminary forecasts for the mid-crop (May-Sept) now centre on 180,000 tonnes, but could be reviewed in June depending on rainfall.
Rains have been favourable, despite a dry period in February, they added.
"There are a large range of factors but the number of pods on trees is quite easily measured," said one. "(Tree) canopies have also been in better shape."
